story: On Friday, Buckingham Palace confirmed the news of his death, mere months before his th birthday, saying that he passed away peacefully last Friday morning at Windsor Castle.Since then people across the world have been sharing their condolences and been paying tribute to the late Duke, including here in East Lothian.Over the years the Duke of Edinburgh has visited East Lothian on several occasions, both solo and with the Queen, to whom he was married to for more than  years.From Haddington and North Berwick to Musselburgh and the opening of Yellowcraig Caravan Park in , he has visited several parts of the county over his  years.One of his first visits is believed to be in  with the then Princess Elizabeth, a year before her coronation.Over the years he re-visited the county on several occasions.Another was  when he inspected the British Legion parade in North Berwick, he also opened Yellowcraig Caravan park in .He has also visited Haddington on numerous occasions, in ,  and .Prince Philiprsquos last public visit is believed to be with the Queen, who was  years old at the time, to Musselburgh Racecourse in , when the couple helped it celebrate its th birthday. The visit came a year before he retired from public le.The Queenrsquos previous visit to the course was in  when she opened a stand named after her, the Queens Stand.Here are some of the many pictures from the Duke of Edinburghrsquos visits to East Lothian over the years in a gallery for you to enjoy.

title: east-lothian-courier-peeps-past-making-news-25-50-100-years-ago
story: A CAMPAIGN to save a local woodland was on the front page of the East Lothian Courier on April , .Friends of the Earth joined about  local people at a public meeting in Stenton Village Hall to discuss tactics to save up to  ancient sessile oak trees in Pressmennan Wood from being felled to make fence posts in Germany.The campaigners, who enlisted the sympathy of TV naturalist David Bellamy, feel let down by the authorities they thought existed to protect their woodlands and the legal processes which allow such felling to take place.A petition against the felling now has , signatures and a few of the campaigners have been given an emergency number to ring ndash in case they hear the chainsaws being moved in.Jess Christman from the East Lothian Community Woodland Trust said he counted , trees in Pressmennan but because the figure includes many other species, campaigners are now worried that the felling figure represents around  per cent of the ancient oaks....and  years agoA DEBATE was held on whether Dunbar should be part of the Borders or East Lothian, reported The Haddingtonshire Courier on April , .At their last meeting, Dunbar Town Council agreed to ask the District Council for their views on a possible merging with the Borders District instead of with the East Lothian District as proposed under the White Paper proposals on local government reform.On Tuesday evening when the District Council met, the possibility was flung out quite unceremoniously, the district council being almost unanimously agreed that such a move would be to the detriment of Dunbar and adjacent areas of East Lothian.On Wednesday, when the Town Council heard their suggestion had been rejected, they decided to take no further action....and  years agoA MAN and woman were rescued near Port Seton Harbour after they were spotted in dficulty, reported The Haddingtonshire Courier on April , .On Saturday afternoon a boat hired from a rowing boat stance at Port Seton was observed to be in dficulties.The occupants ndash a man and a woman ndash were apparently unaccustomed to rowing and had allowed the boat to run into the rocks near the east harbour.Fortunately the boat ran between the spits of rock, but the endeavours of the man to get out of the boat seemed likely to end in a calamity as every time he endeavoured to land the boat canted and threatened to capsize.

title: tims-book-road-legends-chapter-ten
story: ldquoSo exactly why is Fionn MacCoul buried here  he asked.Izzy promised she would tell the story later, when they reached the site where legend tells he was killed by a giant.Then, at Finnrsquos request, they walked to nearby Finlarig Castle.Izzy had always felt the castle had a sombre atmosphere, and so it did, even on this sun-drenched afternoon.Maybe itrsquos because it is quietly hidden away from the tourist trail, its unstable ruins concealed by old trees.Normally a tranquil place feels magical, but the grim deeds said to have been committed here darken the feelings.Izzy had already told Finn of the castle and he wanted to see the beheading pit and hanging tree.It was another built by the Campbell chief lsquoBlack Duncan of the castlesrsquo at the beginning of the s ndash such a ruthless man, andaccounts of him were true, very cruel even for his time.At Finlarig, it is said, he enacted his lsquojusticersquo, in particular against the MacGregors, whose land he had taken and whom he hunted mercilessly.Finn stood in the pit where, according to tradition, noble victims were executed.Their Campbell persecutors could watch and gloat from a window above in the tower.Nearby was the hanging tree, where people of lesser status were said to have met their end.Finn found the overgrown steps that led to the summit of the small hill on which the tree grew.They stood on the spot where so many condemned men would have had their last view of this world.ldquoYoursquore right, aunty, this place does have a bit of a gothic atmosphere, especially when you know that so many people were hanged on the branches of this tree.Izzy nodded: ldquoBut remember, Finn, eventhis is the original hanging tree, then it is innocent, she said as they stood under its boughs.ldquoThe poor thing was used to commit terrible crimes, she put her hand on its trunk, ldquobut it wasnrsquot the treersquos fault.Finn wasnrsquot sureshe was joking itrsquos just a tree, how could it be blamed He put it down to his auntrsquos love of nature.She often spoke asplants and animals were like people.Finn looked around.ldquoCan you tell me a story about this place  he asked.Izzy thought for a moment, then agreed.They sat on a stone by an old holly tree in the sunshine and Izzy told two stories.First, the tale of a wedding at the castle interrupted by MacDonalds lting cattle.Then she told the tale of Marion Campbell, a daughter of a powerful Campbell chief.She had been promised to a man she didnrsquot love, but instead she eloped with Gregor Roy MacGregor, the chief of the MacGregors.ldquoThe sad thing is, explained Izzy, ldquothat beforehand the MacGregors and Campbells had been close allies for many generations, but then a feud over land and power developed.So Gregor Roy was forced into the hills as an outlaw, and Marion willingly joined him, marrying him against her fatherrsquos wishes.ldquoDespite their tough le, said Izzy, ldquothey deeply loved each other.Finn was fascinated as Izzy told Finn stories of their adventures of how they lived in the wilds, living in secret hideouts, hunted by the warriors of Marionrsquos father.She told the tale of how Gregor once escaped his pursuers by leaping over a river and how Marion gave birth to their first son in a cave.ldquoThey wrought vengeance on the Campbells, lting their cattle, said Izzy, ldquobut eventually they were found and Gregor was beheaded by a Campbell chief called Grey Colin in .ldquoIn the beheading pit  asked Finn.ldquoNo, not here, said Izzy, ldquobut at another castle at the east end of Loch Tay."Some accounts say poor Marion was forced to watch, and afterwards she composed a beautul lament, which is a sad song."She wrote it for her son, to explain to him what had happened to his father.Izzy recited a verse she could remember: ldquoEven in snow and blizzards, And days with all the seasons, Gregor would find a hollow for me, In which we would sleep cosily.ldquoWow, what a story. What happened to her after  asked Finn.Izzy shook her head: ldquoNobody knows, she disappears from history, but her son Alistair later avenged his fatherrsquos death and so the feuding continued, which explains the grim deeds at this castle.ldquoMaybe her son protected her after and hid her to keep her safe, wondered Finn.ldquoThatrsquos a nice thought, maybe.Finn stood up and walked around.ldquoIt would be betterfolks could just get on, donrsquot you think! he announced.ldquoAgreed! said Izzy.They walked back to the village.They had a much-needed wash with hot water and Finn called his mum.After a while, he poked his head out of the phone box: ldquoMum wants to talk to you.Izzy knew how dficult this time was for her sister, being separated from her son overnight for the first time in four years.But Izzy was trusted by her and Finnrsquos attachment to his aunt was very strong and made him feel safe.He was obviously missing his mother, but he seemed to be enjoying the journey and his moods had been better, so it was decided the journey could continue.ldquoRemember, mumrsquos back from Spain on Monday eve.ldquoI know, smiled Izzy, ldquowe will be there to meet her, I promise.After the call, they did some shopping and made a quick visit to the Folk Museum, which was housed in the old mill by the side of the river.Izzy wanted to show Finn St Fillanrsquos Stones, which were on display there ndash a tale to tell later when they went for a swim in his pool.As they walked back onto the bridge, Izzy had a surprise.She unlocked the gate which led to the old MacNab burial ground, where chiefs of the clan lie in a walled enclosure, their clan folk in the surrounding ground.ldquoItrsquos actually an island in the middle of the river, explained Izzy.ldquoIts name means yellow island. It was a prehistoric fort before it was a burial ground.Finn nodded as he walked round the edge, looking through the trees down at the river as it roared, then calmed its way to Loch Tay.Izzy spotted a carving of the MacNab crest, with an image of the head of a MacNeish chief, a reminder of a famous incident in the clanrsquos history.ldquoIrsquom getting hungry, aunty, said Finn.She had a plan for tea.They would eat within the ruins of Rob Royrsquos house at Auchinchisallen in Glen Dochart.It was a -minute drive west of Killin.They parked at a small layby just past the small bridge that took the busy traffic over the burn called Allt Coire Chaorach.ldquoThat there  asked Finn, pointing at the ruins.ldquoLooks like mostly a pile of stones with a chimney.ldquoItrsquos called Rob Royrsquos house, letrsquos have our tea there, said Izzy.ldquoReally, it was his house  How do we get to it It was a good question.Once they got over the gate, they followed a narrow bracken-covered path.They got scratched as they scrambled up a steep slope, but suddenly they were on the top and the ruined house was in front of them.They were only a short distance from the road, but it felt like a dferent world.Finn stood on a large stone that once formed part of the foundations and looked up at the one gable end that was still standing.No, it wasnrsquot just a pile of stones, he thought, he could see it had been a house.Finn scanned the landscape around him.Occasional traffic could be heard not far below, but the road seemed engulfed and made insignicant by the mountains and hills that dominated the view.A herd of highland cattle were grazing nearby.ldquoLook, look! We have our own Highland cows! Finn called to his aunt.ldquoPerfect, she said as she her puffed her way to the house.Finn jumped from the stone down to his aunt.ldquoSorry, let me help, he said.ldquoLetrsquos get set up said Izzy, laying the heavy rucksack down.Finn went for a closer look at the cattle while Izzy found a safe place to sit within the ruins.She got out the camping stove and began to cook.Finn joined her and they stared at the pasta as it twirled in the boiling water.The cows came to watch, standing in a row, tails twitching with a fascinated look on their faces.ldquoYoursquore right in what you said, aunty, remarked Finn between mouthfuls of pasta.Izzy curled her eyebrows not sure what he was referring to.ldquoFood tastes much better when itrsquos cooked outside, in a place like this, he explained with a big sauce-covered grin.The sun was now lowering in the sky and Izzy could feel the air finally cooling.The huge presence of Ben More was casting shadows in the glen.She took out her small fire dish, screwed on its legs and placed it carefully within the ruins, away from any vegetation.Finn suggested moving some stones to make more comfortable seats.ldquoWe are guests here, said Izzy, ldquowe are sitting amongst old ruins, and we must leave them exactly as we found them. Even our wee fire must leave no trace. There used to be a sign here telling people about this place, but people just didnrsquot respect it, theyrsquod damaged it or trash it, so the sign was taken away. We know better, so we are welcome guests.Finn nodded. He initially felt upbraided, but his aunt gave him a kind smile which changed the meaning of her words.Instead of feeling scolded, he felt a strange sense of privilege that hersquod been taught something important.ldquoThink how long this house has been here, said Izzy, who looked up at the gable end with the chimney.ldquoThat standing wall was added later, but it is said Rob built the original house here in . It was a time when he was a hunted outlaw. This was Campbell country when he lived here, but he was under the protection of a Campbell chief, how ironic was that  Robrsquos mother had been a Campbell, and yoursquove seen how MacGregors could be both enemies and family with Campbells.She pointed at the base of the ruins: ldquoThose stones are the foundations of the old walls. Now close your eyes for a moment, Finn. Imagine we are in the house in Robrsquos time. There are no windows, a thatched roof above us and a peat fire is in the middle, with a smoky heat filling the room. Now open your eyes, can you see the house as it used to be Finn opened his eyes and looked around.ldquoYes, I think so.ldquoCan you smell the peat smoke in your imagination ldquoI donrsquot know what it smells like aunty.ldquoItrsquos a sweet smoke.ldquoI smell it now.ldquoNow look up, can you see how the soot from the fire has made the rafters of the roof all black ldquoYeah, itrsquos all sooty.ldquoWe are sitting in the very place of the story, said Izzy. ldquoRight where you are, sat Rob Roy himself.ldquoNo aunty, hersquos next to me, otherwise hersquoll be on my knee, joked Finn.ldquoAll right then, of course, hersquos next to you, chuckled his aunt. She pointed to the small fire crackling in the fire dish.ldquoHersquos looking into the peat fire, thinking about his we and children. Then there is a knock at the doorhellip

title: belhaven-bridge-improvements-planned-allow-better-access
story: Thousands of locals and tourists use the Belhaven Bridge ndash also known as the Bridge to Nowhere ndash when crossing the Biel Water to access Belhaven Bay each year.However, with the sea continually moving sand away from the bridge, large boulders are being exposed, leaving many people struggling to navigate a safe route.Community Windpower, which owns and operates Aikengall Community Windfarms in the Lammermuir Hills, has stepped in to meet the cost of the work required on the bridge, with a grant of pound, from its community benefit funds.Councillor Norman Hampshire, who represents the Dunbar and East Linton ward on East Lothian Council, was thrilled to secure the much-needed funding.He said: ldquoWersquore delighted and very grateful that Community Windpower is helping us to carry out the vital work to improve Belhaven Bridge, as we had no other source of financial support.ldquoAccess to the beach side of the bridge is extremely poor and I watched many people last summer have to clamber on rocks and boulders to leave the beach at high tide.ldquoBoth sides of the bridge will be improved and the renovated bridge will have a much safer and longer pathway either side for those using it, but it wonrsquot stop the bridge being left lsquostrandedrsquo at high tide.ldquoAnd, with an increasing number of people crossing Biel Water at low tide to access the beach, to surf, paddle board, swim or simply enjoy the sandy beach, the work is needed to avoid any potential future accidents.Work on the bridge and walkway will include increasing the height andof the walkways and adding handrails.It is hoped that work can start this month but it is subject to both the weather and Covid- restrictions.Diane Wood, community benefits director at Community Windpower, said: ldquoThe Belhaven Bridge is an iconic sight in East Lothian and wersquore really pleased that our community benefit fund can help ensure the crossing is safer for people to use.ldquoWith Covid- meaning more people are enjoying Belhaven beach and the amazing activities available, as a local business we want to continue supporting the area as we have done since .ldquoIndeed, Belhaven Surf Centre near the bridge, which is proving to be a catalyst for people coming to the beach, was built with the help of pound, of funding from Community Windpower and BeGreen in .ldquoWe look forward to seeing the upgraded bridge and trying it out, when conditions allow.Dunbar Community Council has also been involved in looking to seeaccess to the beach can be improved.: Attempts being made to improve access to popular beachPippa Swan, chairwoman of the group, has been working with the local authority to seethere is a solution which would enable people in wheelchairs, with mobility issues or with buggies or prams to cross the Biel Water safely.Last year, trial holes were dug to determine the ground conditions to the west of the bridge.However, it was found the bedrock was ldquoquite a long way below the surface, which meant any solution could prove expensive.Further consideration is to be given to a location to the east of the bridge.

title: kiltwalkers-span-globe-muirfield-riding-therapy
story: Their challenge, which began in January, is raising funds for Muirfield Riding Therapy , based at West Fenton, near Gullane.The walkers had no idea thenthey would reach their target of logging enough team miles to circumnavigate the world by the Virtual Kiltwalk weekend on April .But with two months under their belts, theyrsquove already covered a staggering , miles.Organisers of The Kiltwalk, named as the UKrsquos fth biggest mass participation fundraising event, switched to virtual events in  due to the coronavirus pandemic, raising pound million in the process.In January , the Kiltwalk crew launched another virtual event, Scotlandrsquos Virtual Kiltwalk Weekend, April -. Kiltwalkers were encouraged to take on a challenge of their choice.Supporters jumped at the chance to raise funds for MRT ndash a volunteer-led centre, providing pioneering, le-changing, equine therapy, free.Established in , it is a member group of Riding for the Disabled Association UK.The riders are people with a wide range of disabilities and le-affecting conditions, both physical and mental.Caroline Bacigalupo, from Port Seton, MRT coach and founder of the charityrsquos lsquoRound the World in  Daysrsquo challenge, said: ldquoWe had loads of fun training for last yearrsquos Kiltwalk, despite the pandemic. It kept us fit and motivated, and so we wanted to do something challenging again, to help keep team spirit going over winter lockdown.ldquoWersquove all been missing going on holiday or just visiting friends who live further away, so this inspired us to create our lsquoRound the World in  Daysrsquo challenge.ldquoOur team have been choosing a destination to aim for and logging their miles.Team MRT Virtual Kiltwalker Shirley Duff, a Gullane resident, has been logging her miles since January .She said: ldquoI left Gullane and made it to Belfast to visit my sister. Then onto Dublin to visit my brother and best friends and onto Wexford to visit my other brother. Now making my way back to Gullane ndash about  miles to go.Meanwhile, the Sutton family, from East Linton, are aiming to lsquoreachrsquo Antayla in Turkey for a beach break by April .ldquoWe started with a team of three but wersquove now got around  people logging their miles to help us reach our goal of , miles. We cannot believe the result at this point, two months in, to be at over , already is an incredible effort, said Miss Bacigalupo who also works for catering giant BaxterStorey. The catering firm have fielded several teams in support of MRTrsquos Round the World goal.Not only has the MRT team been putting in the miles but theyrsquove also been putting in fundraising effort. The team fundraising total is standing at pound, smashing their original target by pound,.Fundraising manager Debs McLaughlin, from Gullane, said that the event would play a big part in their fundraising this year, especially due to philanthropist Sir Tom Hunter and his  per cent top up to all Kiltwalkersrsquo fundraising totals.She said: ldquoPeople have been so generous in their support.ldquoWersquod like to say a huge thank you to everyone whorsquos donated so far.ldquoThe Kiltwalk is a fantastic fundraiser, allowing us to continue to fundraise safely and raise awareness of our work during lockdown.ldquoBut perhaps most importantly, itrsquos about having a bit of fun together during this tough time.She added: ldquoWersquove got riders logging their miles out hacking on our therapy ponies, the ponies get exercised, we get miles logged.ldquoWe even have someone supporting us from Dubai, clocking up miles on his bike in the desert, and someone  supporting us by doing circuits of a helideck on a ship at work in the Gulf of Oman.The team can be supported by visiting muirfieldridingtherapy.org.uk

title: preston-lodge-pupils-praised-ahead-returning-school
story: Gavin Clark wished pupils well as they started their Easter break earlier this month.Youngsters willto the Prestonpans secondary school on a full-time timetable following the school holidays.The headteacher urged everyone connected with the school to reflect on where they had been and look to the future.He said: ldquoAs we come to the end of yet another most unusual term, I would like to thank all of our staff, our students and their families for everything that has been done to make the last three months such a success.ldquoThe challenges have been enormous, and things havenrsquot always run smoothly, but we have all come through this really well together, and the Preston Lodge family enters the Easter break in good spirits, looking forward to a fullof all students on April .

title: new-musselburgh-grammar-headteacher-ready-make-history
story: Asked how she felt about her new appointment, which has brought her from the tropics to the Honest Toun, the -year-old mum-of-three told the Courier she was ldquodelighted.She said she did not realise she would become the schoolrsquos first female headteacher until the present headteacher, Colin Gerrie ndash who is bound for a new job in Dubai ndash told her.ldquoThat really is history in the making, along with an incredible -year anniversary to look forward to, she added.Ms Hannan said: ldquoI love that the schoolis at the heart of such a strong, vibrant community, and the staff, pupils and parents I have met so far have been so welcoming.Born in Dunfermline, her family moved to the Solomon Islands in the southern Pacic, part of the British Commonwealth, when she was three.Her father was a business studies teacher at the secondary college in the capital Honiara and her mother worked for the government.They moved back to Edinburgh in  but the lure of living in the tropics was too strong and they ed to the Pacic in , this time to Vanuatu.She attended the local secondary school in the capital Port Vila, then the family ed to Edinburgh when she was in S to sit her Standard Grades.ldquoI had the best childhood and didnrsquot appreciate it at the time, she said.After graduating from Strathclyde University in , she worked in the hospitality industry, then went to Moray House to train as a teacher in .Ms Hannan, who lives in Edinburgh, said: ldquoTeaching is the best job in the world and I wouldnrsquot want to do anything .ldquoI trained as a history teacher and completed my probationary year at Tynecastle High School in Edinburgh. I then moved to Dunfermline High School, becoming head of faculty in  and depute rector in .ldquoI took up post as headteacher at Drummond Community High School [in Edinburgh] in June . I have been very lucky to work with brilliant young people, staff and parents in all three schools.Looking ahead to being at the helm of Musselburgh Grammar as the country emerges from the Covid- pandemic, she said: ldquoBeing a headteacher is an incredible responsibility and honour. Families are putting their trust in you to make sure their children have the best school experience possible to make sure they are prepared for le after school, and this is particularly true as we come out of lockdown, as so many things have changed.ldquoLockdown was very challenging on many levels but there have been silver linings to embrace, such as teachers developing their digital learning, and now that SQA exams have been cancelled for the second year in a row, important ongoing discussions about how young people should be assessed.Our post-Covid world presents some challenges but many more opportunities to shape the education our children need, so itrsquos an exciting time to be in education.She added: ldquoI think lockdown also confirmed the importance of community, kindness and looking after each other, and that is what schools are all about.ldquoHeadship is such a rewarding job and I know that there have been many positive changes under Colin Gerriersquos leadership.ldquoIrsquom committed to taking the school from good to great ndash as the Grammarrsquos motto says, lsquothe best school in Scotlandrsquo, with a dedicated staff team, enthusiastic students, and parentsrsquo support.Ms Hannan has two sons, a daughter and two cats.Her eldest son has left school, her daughter is in S and youngest son in P.She said: ldquoLike so many families, juggling work and home schooling in lockdown was challenging for us all and wersquore all looking forward to getting back to school properly.Ms Hannan takes up the post when pupilsto school in August following the holidays.

title: gardeners-arms-may-last-orders-plans-housing
story: The Gardeners Arms closed nearly three years ago and, with no one coming forward to breathe new le into the pub, it could be transformed into housing.East Lothian Council is weighing up a planning application which would see homes created on each of the buildingrsquos three storeys.Agents representing DSI Properties Ltd, which is behind the plans for the building, said that attempts had previously been made to see The Gardeners Arms reopen.They said: ldquoThe loss of commercial premises within the main business area of the town is something the authority tries to control however, even before the current crisis, it is fair to say that the licence trade and in particular small non-food premises have been struggling to survive.ldquoThe previous owners attempted but failed to find tenants for the premises.ldquoThere was no interest and they were forced to put the property up for sale, with no interest other than that of the applicants.Plans show two-bedroom flats on each of the three floors, with the upper two floors including an en-suite bathroom.The developers state: ldquoIt is clear that an alternative use for the property needs to be foundit is not to fall into disrepair.Similarly, they claim that the market for a pub has ldquonot been good for some time and will become even more dficult following the current Covid outbreak and the economic fallout from this.A decision on the proposals is expected by the end of next month.The name for the pub dates back hundreds of years, with The Fraternity of Gardeners of East Lothian once based in the town.They purchased a property on a corner of Market Street which contained an inn, which is still known as the Gardeners Arms.The plans for the Kilpair Street building were discussed by the townrsquos community council on Tuesday evening.

title: celebrations-planned-haddington-mark-end-lockdown
story: Discussions are taking place to see what could be organised to mark the historic occasion, with family events and a permanent memorial among the options being considered.Paul Kinnoch, from the townrsquos Tyneside Tavern and Mazzoli Italian Kitchen, is among those involved in planning a celebratory event.A promotions group ndash made up of members of Haddington Business Community Partnershipand other members of the public ndash is exploring the possibility of some sort of festivity taking place.Mr Kinnoch, who heads up the HBCP sub-group, said ldquoa community day was being considered for the town and added: ldquoIt would be to celebrate everybody that made a dference during the lockdown period and create a huge event, similar to what we did for Haddington , to bring the community together.ldquoThe provisional consideration is that it would take place in spring , which would give us time to organise the event and presuming things have opened up in terms of volume of people that can attend and the guidelines in terms of things that we can do.ldquoWe would like to look at some kind of visible tribute as well, which would feature in a location in Haddington.ldquoWhether that would be a plaque in a garden or a sculpture or some sort of memorial ndash what we would do there is put it out to the community, to the public, to see what they would like and what type of memorial they would like as well.Three years ago, groups from throughout the town came together to mark  years of Haddington becoming a royal burgh.The Haddington  celebrations were spread out throughout much of , with a celebratory event taking place at the East Haugh.Mr Kinnoch felt that the event worked well and there had been people calling for similar celebrations to take place in the following years.Now, something similar could take place, with a procession leaving from the townrsquos refurbished Corn Exchange making its way to a site of celebration.During the lockdown restrictions, members of the public stepped up to help neighbours and strangers during challenging times.People from throughout the town collected shopping and prescriptions, as well as helping keep gardens tidy, producing face shields and masks.Originally, discussions took place to consider the possibility of a monument being created at the East Lothian Community Hospital, on the site of the former Roodlands Hospital.However, other sites will also now be considered.Pat Lemmon, vice-chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, is among those involved in the discussions with the promotions group.She added: ldquoIt would be good for Haddington to have some kind of tribute.

title: lothian-e-waiting-times-increase
story: Statistics show that . per cent of people were seen at hospital AE departments across the health board area within the four-hour standard timeframe in February ndash down more than three per cent from January. In March , the rate was . per cent.The Edington Hospital in North Berwick ndash which has a nurse-led minor injuries unit ndash was the only provider in the Lothians to achieve a  per cent rating in this category.Across Scotlandrsquos health boards, only NHS Ayrshire and Arranand NHS Bordersfared worse than Lothian.The data from Public Health Scotland also shows that since August last year, the number of monthly attendances at AEs across NHS Lothian has continuously decreased, from , in August to , in February.Since , the national standard is that  per cent of patients wait no longer than four hours from arrival to admission, discharge or transfer.The recent figures show that only hospitals in Shetland, Tayside and the Western Isles had a percentage higher than .Across Scotland, there was a large drop in attendance at AE compared to a year earlier.There were , attendances to AE services in Scotland in February . per cent were seen and admitted, transferred or discharged within four hours.In February , the number of attendances was ,.A total of , people spent more than eight hours in an AE department  spent more than  hours, with . per cent of attendances leading to a hospital admission.Jacquie Campbell, chief officer for acute services at NHS Lothian, said: ldquoWe have a clear system to ensure patients who need urgent care the most are seen first at AE. However, additional infection control and physical distancing measures can extend waiting times. In line with national policy, wersquove been asking patients to access the right care by dialling  firstthey think they need AE but it is not le-threatening, to be directed to the right service or given an appointment to attend hospital conveniently and safely.

title: teacher-enjoys-health-benefits-taking-outdoor-swimming
story: Members of Pans Dookers have enjoyed the water off the East Lothian coastline, visiting beaches at Gullane and Longniddry.Lynn Paton is now a fully fledged member and enjoyed  consecutive days in the water, reaching the milestone at the end of March, despite admitting she was initially worried about what lurked beneath the surface.The Prestonpans resident said: ldquoIt was probably what might touch me in the water.ldquoIrsquom going to be honest, I had a fear of jellyfish and anything slimy touching me.ldquoI spent most of my summers as a child in Portobello and it was not particularly clean.ldquoIt was just a fear of east coast water and I think the cold definitely was something I thought I would never manage.The mum-of-two previously swam occasionally at the townrsquos Mercat Gait Centre but has fallen in love with outdoor swimming with the Pans Dookers, which was started by Sarah Morrice, a local indoor and outdoor swimming teacher.Lynn braved the waters throughout much of the winter, despite rain, sleet and snow.During the winter months, many swimmers, some clad in wetsuits and others in swimming costumes, were in the water for about  minutes.But, as the weather improves and water temperatures rise, Lynn, who teaches at Haddington Primary School, is now in the water for more than half an hour.The -year-old, who is often joined by her daughters Isla, , and Charlotte, , encouraged other people to enjoy the water and explained her initial thoughts about seeing friends in the water.She said: ldquoI had watched my friends do it for a couple of months and thought they were absolutely crazy.ldquoThey challenged me to stop calling them crazy and to have a go myself.ldquoIt was last August, just before the schools started back, that I took the plunge one morning with Kimberley Mitchell and a group of other ladies from Pans Dookers.ldquoJust from day dot, I was absolutely hooked and could see the benefits straight away.ldquoI have always loved swimming but, with pools being closed, it was a dficult one.ldquoQuite quickly, I was feeling the health benefits of wild swimming ndash both physically and mentally.ldquoEverybody during the pandemic has struggled in their own way.ldquoWith my job and aspects of it, it was not easy sometimes having worked in the school hub and then supporting my own girls through their online learning was a bit of a challenge.ldquoThe swimming definitely was something that eased that and the health benefits were just a really, really positive thing.ldquoI have always suffered with migraines and they have not been as frequent since doing wild swimming.Swimmers, ranging in age from five to , meet depending on tide times and the weather at dferent times of day to enjoy a dip.

title: covid-scotland-doses-coronavirus-vaccine----now
story: Coronavirus travel restrictions in Scotland have been eased and more people will be able to meet up outdoors, thanks to a reduction in prevalence of the virus as well as progress with the rollout of the vaccine.However, itrsquos highly likely vaccination rates will play a key role in determining continued progress as restrictions ease.And as confidence rebuilds, and Scotland emerges from lockdown,plenty of question marks still hang in the air.And for the hundreds of thousands who have now recieved two doses of the vaccine, they may be wondering - what now WeaskedDr Georgia Perona-Wright, who is a senior lecturer in Immunology at the University of Glasgow, to weigh in.Yes, you can. The good news though is that itrsquos very much less likely that you will get covidyoursquore vaccinated, compared to someone who isnrsquot.Even better, in the unlikely event that you do catch Covid after being vaccinated, you are much less likely to get severe symptoms or be hospitalised thanyou had not been vaccinated.The clinical trials for the Pfizer vaccine reported a % efficacy, which means that the number of people who showed symptoms of covid during the time of the trial was % lower in the vaccinated group than in a comparison group who were not vaccinated.Data collected since the trials, as the vaccines have begun to be used widely, has confirmed these numbers, so the vaccines are very effective on a population scale. On a inidual scale, though, there is still a chance that you might be one of the very few people who is vaccinated and still gets infected it is possible, just very much less likely than without a vaccine.One extra point to add here is that the vaccines take time to work.The vaccine is not a instant shot of protection it is a way to train your immune system, so that your immune system will then protect you. It takes - weeks or so for the immune system to respond so, evenyou are someone who has a superb immune response to the vaccine, you are still not protected until - weeks after the jag.Some cases of people being infected with covid after the vaccination are because they were exposed to the virus during this - week window. Be especially cautious during this time.Just as the vaccines make it much less likely that yoursquoll get infected, they also make it much less likely that you will be able to infect others ndash but in both cases the answer is that the chances are much reduced, but not zero.We donrsquot fully understand why some people are fully protected and others are not it might be that you have a slightly quirky immune system, or are immunosuppressed it might be that you are exposed to an unusually high dose of the virus.It might be something in your genes or environment that makes you a particularly good target for the virus.When the first trials were conducted to test how well the vaccines work, the data that was collected measured the number of people who showed symptoms of disease. This number was reduced % in the Pfizer trial.The trials did not attempt to measure whether vaccinated people could still be infectious. We have some really encouraging data now, collected after the trials from countries where vaccines have been used widely, showing that vaccination does also reduce transmission ndash meaning that vaccinated people are less likely to infect others than people who are not vaccinated.This is what we expected and hoped for, and itrsquos really good to see. This is why being vaccinated not only protects ourselves, but also others.Viruses cannot live for long periods on their own they need a person to provide a home.If you are successfully vaccinated, then your body is trained to refuse entry to the virus, denying it that home.When only a few people are vaccinated, the virus can fairly easily find another person, another home to occupy. When very many people are vaccinated, finding a home becomes much more of a challenge, and the virus is condemned to a lonely death outside.The idea of working together by using our immune systems to reduce the number of opportunities that the virus has to gain a foothold and spread is whatrsquos called ldquoherd immunity.Even the rare people in whom the vaccine didnrsquot work very well can be protected this way, as other peoplersquos vaccinations mean that they too are less likely to encounter the virus.No. The importance of a face mask is that it is a barrier to stop you infecting other people.We still need to be cautious to avoid infection, and to avoid infecting others, until the amount of virus circulating in our communities falls.The Covid vaccines are one part of our toolkit for reducing the amount of virus circulating. They make it less likely yoursquoll get infected, less likely yoursquoll get sick, and less likely yoursquoll breathe out the virus and spread it to others.But there is still a small chance that each of these steps can happen, and so facemasks, space and distance are all still needed just now.The gradual easing of restrictions that is beginning just now is possible because wersquove successfully driven case numbers down, in part through the vaccination programme.If we can keep this up, then we will get to a point when case numbers are low enough that restrictions will ease yet further, and facemasks might then become optional in more places.We are optimistic that immunity will last ndash but not yet certain.The first people to receive the Covid vaccines were only vaccinated  months ago, so we know that vaccines can generate immunity that lasts at least  months.We know that the majority of people who have been infected with the SARS-CoV virus, that causes Covid, also have persistent immune cells and good antibody levels, even a year after infection.There was a lot of fear that immunity would not last, and there are been some prominent cases where people have been shown to be infected twice ndash so in those particualr people, immunity was either not persistent or not ever good enough.But for the majority of people, infection has led to persistent immunity, so far.Another piece of encouraging news is that particular immune cells, essential for protection, were still detectable last year in people who were infected in  with SARS, which was a severe infection caused by a similar coronavirus to the one that causes Covid.So we are optimistic, but will only know for certain when more time has passed.Another twist here, is whether immunity generated by having one of the current vaccines will be effective against any virus iants: lasting immunity might not be useful,the virus mutates and can escape that immunity. But there are grounds for optimism here toohellip... There are two situations in which a booster might be useful.The first one isimmunity doesnrsquot last long enough without a booster, and in that case a third jag is definitely a possible solution.The second one isthe virus mutates or ies, and we need to update our vaccines to match the new iants. The coronavirus that causes Covid is one that is known to mutate ndash thatrsquos a normal part of its biology.The flu virus is another example of a virus that we know mutates, and thatrsquos why flu vaccines are updated and given every year.But the Covid vaccines have held up well so far: the vaccines currently being used in the UK were designed against the original version of the virus, but have done very well in reducing disease and blocking transmission of the B.. Kent iant, for example.The immune response generated by the vaccines is strong, and evenit is two fold less effective against a new iant, there is a good chance the remaining immune response will still be enough to prevent severe disease and slow the spread of the virus.Another piece of good news is the way that these new vaccines have been designed makes it a relatively simple process to update them,new iants make that necessary.If we do need boosters, that too should be achievable.The gradual easing of restrictions that have begun now reflects the success of our collective ability to reduce the amount of virus circulating, and getting people fully vaccinated is a large part of this success.I hope that this gradual process will continue as the vaccination programme is completed, and more normality will be achieved in each step.That said, we are still a long way away from everyone having both doses, as we need vaccinations to be completed globally before any inidual country can fully relax.Within the UK, the vaccination programme is currently planned for all adults, but vaccines for teenagers and younger children are only in the stage of clinical trials.Globally, some restrictions on international travel might need to persist until global vaccination rates increase, and those gobal vaccination rates depend on politics and cooperation between nations.Another aspect to this question is what normal really means.The pandemic hit us hard and for people whorsquove been bereaved, who have persistent symptoms or Long Covid, or whose jobs and livelihoods have been affected, normal wonrsquot ever be as it was.And as communities, there are also changes both good and bad.Will hand sanitiser provision in supermarkets continue  Will working from home always be more possible  Will high streets rejuvenate  There are opportunities for change here,we want to grasp them but there may also need to be time to heal and recover.

title: work-progressing-400-home-development-longniddry
story: Work at the site ndash being marketed as lsquoLongniddry Villagersquo ndash has been ongoing for more than a year.The East Coast Main Line railway is all that separates the new development from the existing Longniddry settlement.But the site of the new homes is actually where lsquooldrsquo Longniddry once stood, hence its lsquoLongniddry Villagersquo name.This week, ZeroC, part of Places for People, opened the doors to its new show home in the development.Longniddry Village is being developed in partnership with landowners Wemyss and March Estates.Maps dating back to the s show that half of the old village of Longniddry was to the south of where the railway now runs, on the site of the present Longniddry Farm.When John Glassell acquired most of the lands of the village in , the pace of change increased and many of the remaining houses and buildings in the village were cleared for agriculture.The railway arrived in  and land previously owned by Mr Glassell was passed firstly to the House of Argyll and then to the Wemyss and March Estates, with the many new homes being built to the north of the railway line in the s.Allison Sutherland, regional sales and marketing director for Places for People in Scotland, said: ldquoItrsquos been an exciting time for Places for People to deliver our first ZeroC development in East Lothian, which delivers a fresh approach to building homes in the area. The development and house types have been designed to complement the local area, with attractive layouts and flexible living in mind, suitable for a range of customers.ldquoWe have been overwhelmed with the level of interest.Ward councillor Neil Gilbert said it was important that the new homes became part of the existing village. He said a lot of people were ldquoon board with the development and highlighted some improvements being planned for the village through the development.Mr Gilbert said: ldquoThe improvements the money will be doing, particularly on the main street and the bridge under the railway line with traffic lights, have gone down quite well.ldquoObviously, the school needed an injection as well.ldquoLongniddry is an ageing population or was and this should bring the average age down a bit and bring more kids into the school.The development also includes a range of affordable homes for rent exclusively designed for people over  and boasts ldquoextensive open space with a new village green and restored mill pond.Earlier this year, plans for a cafe and offices on the site were approved by East Lothian Council.More than  homes are planned for the site, with three developers working on the first phase.That will see Cruden delivering  new homes, with ZeroC behind  homes and Castle Rock Edin responsible for .

title: boxing-champion-josh-taylor-speaks-preston-lodge-pupils
story: Josh spoke online to a number of pupils from Preston Lodge High School about their achievements and the importance of sport.The boxing star, who attended the school from  to , held the virtual chat with the youngsters ahead of his bid to become the worldrsquos undisputed light welterweight boxing champion.Among the budding sports stars he spoke to were Millie Allan, Nicole Hogg, and Daniel and Ben McCabe.Josh had approached the Prestonpans secondary school to have a chat to the youngsters about lockdown, how they had stayed motivated and what they were looking forward to about ing to school.Millie spoke about her efforts to get youngsters involved in sport.She said: ldquoI feel like that is kind of what you need to do, especially now.ldquoI coach rugby on a Sunday and I do hockey for the school.ldquoAlso, being a sports ambassador, I am just trying to get the kids into any kind of sport, any activity that they can.Footballer Nicole, who plays for Musselburgh Windsor, was then put on the spot when the IBF and WBA Light Welterweight champion asked how many goals she had scored.The secondary school pupil said: ldquoLast season, I got  assists ndash the most assists in my team ndash but I think I only got -odd goals.Finally, Josh, who is preparing for the biggest fight of his career as he takes on fellow double world champion Jose Ramirez in a world title unication bout in Las Vegas, told Daniel and Ben he was ldquobuzzing ahead of the fight next month.Ben said they were ldquoreally big fans of both Josh and fellow Scots boxer Lee McGregor and added: ldquoWe just wanted to wish you all the best for the fight.Josh took time out from his gruelling training schedule to speak to the pupils at the beginning of the month.The school already has an award in his honour, named the Josh Taylor Sports Personality of the Year Award.Afterwards, the Commonwealth Games gold medal winner tweeted: ldquoIt was class to speak with pupils from Preston Lodge and find out how theyrsquove been keeping, amazing to hear the resilience these kids have.ldquoIrsquom coming in with all the belts as soon as I can, bringing them home for Scotland!Chris Thomas, principal teacher support guidance, thanked the boxing world champion for giving up his time.He said: ldquoJosh spoke candidly with the pupils inidually about a range of subjects, including their lockdown experience, their future plans and how they stay motivated.ldquoJosh commented how impressed he was with the Preston Lodge pupilsrsquo motivation but also their sense of community and pride.ldquoAll the pupils wished Josh the best of luck for the upcoming world championship fight.ldquoHopefully we will see Josh back at the school with his winnersrsquo belts!Gavin Clark, the schoolrsquos headteacher, also thanked Josh for speaking to the youngsters.He said: ldquoEveryone at PL is incredibly proud of Josh and his amazing achievements in boxing, and we were really touched that he took the time to catch up with some of our students as he prepares for his next big fight.ldquoJosh has always been really supportive of the school and we all wish him well in May!

title: project-set-tackle-loneliness-isolation
story: On April , North Berwick Coastal Community Connections was established as a separate organisation, after initially being set up as a pilot project of the townrsquos health and wellbeing association.Launched in , it helps those over the age of  with isolation and loneliness. It also gained charitable status last September and is looking forward to developing its range of services.Project officer Carol Stobie has led the project since its establishment but is now being supported by recently appointed befriender coordinator Lisa Brownlie.Alongside Carol and Lisa, the project is overseen by a board of trustees, two members of which are co-chairs Lisa McClure and Robert Burgon.A large team of trained volunteers cover a wide range of skills and experience, work with the projectrsquos members and encourage them to make connections with other iniduals and organisations in the area.The project is now working to secure funding for a three-year period, beginning in October.Mr Burgon said: ldquoNorth Berwick Coastal Community Connections recognises that the issues of social isolation are all too common and have been exacerbated during lockdown.ldquoIt continues to explore ways in which it can provide lasting solutions to these issues.For support or to volunteer, email nbc-communityconnections@outlook

title: dunbar-basics-foodbanks-feasibility-study-given-2-000
story: Dunbar Basics Foodbank is looking at the viability and advantages of the potential new project.The scheme would offer people the chance to make their own choice when it comes to buying food and supplies, while also supporting local retailers.It is hoped the initiative will also help boost the townrsquos High Street, which has also been hit hard by the coronavirus crisis.Now, Community Windpower and BeGreen Dunbar have helped out with pound, issued through their joint Covid- crisis fund.A spokesperson for Community Windpower said that the foodbank needed money to provide fuel top-up cards, a vital part of supporting people heating food and their homes, with many people who use the foodbank also living in fuel poverty.Dunbar Basics Foodbank is a registered charity based at Dunbar Parish Church and has been supporting the local community for seven years.It operates independently from the church and caters for a wide range of people throughout the local community.Previously, the group reported an increase in referrals due to the coronavirus pandemic, with extra volunteers coming forward.Diane Wood, community benefits director at Community Windpower, which operates the Aikengall Community Windfarms in the nearby Lammermuir Hills, was pleased to be able to help out.She said: ldquoWersquore fully aware of the plight many people and families find themselves in due to the Covid- pandemic, which is why wersquore fully behind the fantastic work carried out by Dunbar Basics Foodbank.ldquoThe grant will provide something vital, particularly at this time of year, as many struggle to heat and light their homes.ldquoOur Covid- crisis fund is designed to help a wide range of organisations and people across East Lothian, and wersquoll continue to look at how we can support Dunbar Basics Foodbank in the future.

title: faside-community-kitchen-looking-new-members
story: Farsquoside Community Kitchen delivers meals to more than  people every week.It aims to support the community to alleviate the pressure of food insecurity and food poverty, reduce isolation and relieve hardship, working alongside community partners to do so.To do this, it delivers fresh meals to those in need and offers activities that will improve peoplersquos mental health.The community kitchen was set up last year following the work of Duncan McBride and Joyce Thomson, who cooked about , meals during the first lockdown last spring as part of Tranentrsquos resilience effort in response to the coronavirus pandemic.Ruth Davie, from Fundamental Foods, which set up the emergency food provision in Farsquoside and is guided by the Pennypit Trust, said she was looking for a chef to cook hot meals and Duncan offered his services.Duncan then approached Joyce and her husband Andy, his long-time friends, and soon got them involved.They then spent the next few months making thousands of meals from their base in Tranentrsquos East Lothian Co-operative Bowling Club, where Joyce works behind the bar, and used its kitchens to prepare the meals.They would be in the bowling club about five or six days a week making about  meals a day for those in need.Since then, it has become a registered charity and is keen for local East Lothian residents to join its board and help to continue its work.A spokesperson for Farsquoside Community Kitchen said the charity wanted to recruit members of the local community in East Lothian who ldquoare motivated, experienced and passionate about building back better.The only requirement is that applicants must be over the age of .To find out more information, email tracey@volunteereastlothian.org.uk

title: historic-farm-building-transformed-new-office-hub
story: Wheatrig Business Hub, located two miles from Longniddry, has been created to offer office facilities, with space for social distancing.Anna and William Thomson, who are behind the facility at Wheatrig Farm, encouraged people to get in touch and voice their interest.They said in a statement: ldquoWorking from your spare room or dining room table is, as thousands will attest, far from easy.ldquoWhilst fine in the short term, as a long-term solution home working has its drawbacks: domestic le can cause distractions, technology is not always reliable, and loneliness has been identied as a real issue over recent months.

title: plans-lodged-convert-barn-vet-clinic
story: Lisa Cleeton is looking to convert the barn at Bankton Stables, to the south of the train station.Plans are now with the council, with the local authorityrsquos planning department aiming to make a decision by the end of next month.Ms Cleeton highlighted that the need for the business had been brought about due to the coronavirus pandemic.A supporting statement included with the planning application notes: ldquoDue to this pandemic, I now wish to change my stables from personal use to veterinary physiotherapy clinic as, at present, I cannot go into my clientsrsquo homes to carry out veterinary physiotherapy on their animals.The clinic could be open six days a week, from am to pm Monday to Friday, and then from am to .pm on a Saturday.Ms Cleeton, who expected each appointment to last between  and  minutes, said: ldquoThe clinic would not be open all of these hours as I am able to carry out physiotherapy on other animals in their own stables and paddocks.ldquoI expect client numbers to be approximately  per week.ldquoThere will be no other staff apart from myself.

title: inveresk-street-branded-unremarkable-glazing-firm
story: East Lothian planners refused planning permission for the new windows in the house on Wedderburn Terrace, Inveresk.Planning officers argued that the modern window frames were harmful to the character of the Inveresk conservation area.However agents for CR Smith, who were supported by the home owner in the appeal, argued that the locale of the property was ldquounremarkable.In an appeal statement to East Lothian Councilrsquos local review body, they said: ldquoWhilst the Inveresk Conservation Area in its entirety is undoubtedly worthy of its conservation area status, this stretch of Wedderburn Terrace is comparably unremarkable, without any buildings or vistas that would warrant protection in their own right.Inveresk is a conservation areaThe appeal came after planners refused retrospective permission for the windows and doors of the property to be replaced using PVC.Agents argued that the new material was not only more energy efficient than the original timber frames but offered more security given ldquoa number of house burglaries in the area.They pointed to other properties on the street which had similar window frames, producing a montage of images of other homes in the area to back them up.And they said of the house itself: ldquoIt is a reasonable attempt by a homeowner to improve the energy efficiency and security of his modest and unremarkable home.At the local review body meeting, Councillor Norman Hampshire, chairing, agreed that the new windows on the house, which dates back to the s, did not have an impact on the conservation area.He said: ldquoIf it had been a listed building, I would be minded to go with the officers however, on this building I do not think its impact on the conservation area will be signicant.His view was backed by fellow body members Councillor Jeremy Findlay and Councillor Kenny McLeod, who agreed unanimously to uphold the CR Smith appeal and allow the windows to remain.

title: rachel-ross-appointed-rural-development-director-elevator
story: Elevator works across Scotland to help facilitate the start-up, acceleration and growth of new and existing businesses through its unique delivery of Business Gateway services and a range of accelerator programmes.Providing Business Gateway services across three Scottish regions ndash Aberdeen City and Shire, Tayside and Lanarkshire ndash Elevator is Scotlandrsquos largest provider of these services supporting some , new businesses to start up each year while working with , businesses across Scotland each year.The newly created role will see Rachel drive Elevatorrsquos rural development strategy and explore new strategic business opportunities. Her appointment highlights Elevatorrsquos commitment to supporting the breadth and ersity of businesses across the entire country.A well-known rural business advocate, Rachel owns the iconic Loch Melfort Hotel on Argyllrsquos West coast and has held other senior industry positions including Board Director at Scotland Food and Drink.Most recently she was a Director at leadership consultancy Peoplematters. Supporting iniduals from erse sectors across the Highlands and Islands region, Rachelrsquos role focused on delivering leadership training and development, and coaching and business mentoring for SMEs, rural and high growth Scottish businesses.With an estimatedper cent ofScotlands landarea designated as rural, Elevatorrsquos CEO, Professor Gary McEwan, said Rachelrsquos appointment is a pivotal step in the social enterprisersquos rural development.ldquoDespite the pandemic induced dficulties, we have pushed on with our growth strategy and I am delighted to be welcoming Rachel to our senior leadership team. She has the passion, capability and aspiration to build on our success, expanding our presence and services into new territories.ldquoOur vision for rural town centre regeneration includes enterprise hubs and community hub satellites that support and encourage local networks and collaboration. This is key for the rural sector, to help re-build our economy and strengthen job security, concluded Professor McEwan.On her new role, Rachel commented: ldquoA erse range of new businesses are starting up all over rural Scotland, Elevator provides the support, training and connections to allow these businesses to achieve long-term growth, resilience and adaptability. With improving broadband and the increase in desire for remote working, there is a whole new audience emerging and needing support within the rural community ndash from agriculture to marine, food  drink and tourism.ldquoItrsquos an exciting time for the business and I am delighted to be joining Elevator on this next chapter of its growth journey.FollowElevator onTwitter, LinkedIn or Facebook andfind out morehere.

title: just-five-cases-coronavirus-recorded-east-lothian-last-week
story: Throughout the pandemic, data on the number of coronavirus cases and deaths for Scotland and each local authority area has been recorded and published by Public Health Scotland.Five cases gives East Lothian a seven-day positive rate per , people of just . and a seven-day test positivity rate of . per cent.As well as the data for the county as a whole, each local authority area is split into zones, with people able to find out the number of positive cases in the area they live.For several months at least, one part of East Lothian was an area of concern ndash when a zone records more than three positive cases in seven days.But now no part of East Lothian is an area of concern, as each recorded fewer than two positive cases in the last seven days.Where fewer than two positive cases are recorded, the number is shown as - to protect patient confidentiality.According to the data, the last positive test in East Lothian was recorded last Tuesday .Midlothian also recorded five positive cases over the same time period, with a seven-day positive rate per , people of . Edinburghrsquos seven-day rate is currently . and West Lothianrsquos ..The number of coronavirus deaths in East Lothian for April remains at zero, with the last Covid- death in the county recorded on March .

title: vandalism-north-berwick-law-condemned-mindless
story: The ldquotrig point at the top of North Berwick Law was found at the weekend with ious deep lines and what some people believed could be the initials WILK scratched into its metal surface.The white post, used by Ordnance Survey surveyors as a reference point, was also targeted last month by vandals, who sprayed their tag on the structure.The paint was removed by council workers.Comments by local residents on social media included ldquoAbsolutely mindless vandalism. Must be proud of themselves, making such a contribution to the community, and ldquoThatrsquos actually so mindless. Kids or not. Itrsquos like vandalising your own home.

title: covid-rules-scotland-nicola-sturgeon-confirms-lockdown-easing
story: These changes include the full reopening of retail services and partial reopening of the hospitality sector.The First Minister confirmed that all areas in mainland Scotland will move to Level  meaning that bars, restaurants, retail shops and beauty salons can reopen from Monday.Here, we outline the key points from her briefing and the rules in Level .. The lockdown exit planSpeaking of Scotlands lockdown exit strategy, Nicola Sturgeon said: "Taking all of the recent data into account, I am pleased to be able to confirm today that from Monday  April, those parts of the country that are currently in level  will move to level ."That of course includes all of mainland Scotland."We then expect that all of Scotland will move to level  on Monday  May."That means, for example, that from  May, people will be able to meet in small numbers in each otherrsquos homes, hospitality will reopen more fully, and outdoor contact sport for adults will resume."Then,circumstances permit, I can confirm that we will move to level  on Monday  June, before moving I hope to level  in late June ndash and then to something much more like normality over the course of the summer."Up to four people from two households can socialise indoors in a public place, such as a cafe or restaurant.Hospitality venues like cafes, pubs and restaurants can open until pm indoors ndash but without alcohol ndash and pm outdoors where alcohol is allowed to be consumed.Gyms can open for inidual exercise.All shops, stores and close contact services can open.Tourist accommodation can open with restrictions in place.Driving lessons and tests can resume.Funerals and weddings including post-funeral events and receptions can take place with up to  people, but no alcohol may be served.Indoor attractions and public buildings such as galleries, museums and libraries can open.Travel will also be allowed on this date to other parts of Britain, with reviews planned on journeys to Northern Ireland and the Republic.People on the shielding canto work from MondayFrom next Monday, the Chief Medical Officerrsquos advice will be that people on the shielding list canto the workplace -you cannot work from home.Like everyone ,you can work from home for now, you should.The First Minister said: "The last few months have been dficult for everyone ndash but have been especially dficult for people who are shielding."I am very grateful to you for everything you have done to keep yourselves and others safe. I very much hope that you enjoy being able to get out and about a little bit more, and that the understandable anxiety you have been living with is beginning to reduce."Nicola Sturgeon confirmed that all remaining travel restrictions will be lted on  April for travel anywhere in Scotland, and for travel between Scotland, England and Wales.The Scottish Government will removerestrictions on travel to and from Northern Ireland, the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man - though people should check the rules on entry to each of those territories before they travel.Due to low Covid rates in the Scottish Islands you are askedto take two lateral flow tests before you depart.The First Minister said: "If youre planning to travel to an island, we will encourage you to take  lateral flow tests before you depart."The second test should be on the day that you travel, and the first should be  days earlier."That means thatyou test positive, you have a chance to take a PCR test to confirm the result before you make a final decision on cancelling your visit."Lateral flow testswill be available to anyone from  April - can order online and find info on the Scottish Governmentwebsite or collect from covid testing centres in afternoon or evening.They can be ordered online for delivery to your home ndash you can find information on how to do that on the Scottish Governmentrsquos website.Alternatively, you can collect the tests from Covid testing centres in the afternoon or early evening.Scotland has recorded two deaths from coronavirus and  positive tests in the past  hours, Nicola Sturgeon said.It brings the death toll under this measure ndash of people who first tested positive for the virus within the previous  days ndash to ,.Giving a Covid- update, the First Minister said , people have now tested positive in Scotland, up from , the previous day.The daily test positivity rate is .%, down from .%.There are  people in hospital confirmed to have the virus, up two in  hours, and  patients are in intensive care, down one.Ms Sturgeon said ,, people have received their first dose of a coronavirus vaccine, up , from yesterday, and , have received their second dose.Yes, for outdoors, such as beer gardens, isalcohol permitted with six people from six households.Yes, all non-essential shops will be open for business so you will be able to head to your favourite retailers.Yes, from April  you will be able to travel anywhere across Scotland.However, as lockdown levels change, people in Level must not enter Levels - or Level  area unless for a permitted reason.Staycations will be permitted with travel restrictions lted and tourist accommodation will reopen.However, socialising rules must still apply.International travel will remain not permitted.For indoors pubs, bars, restaurants and cafes are also set to reopen on April  ndash however, this is only for meals and non-alcoholic drinks.They will be given a strict pm curfew and onlysix people from two households are allowed.Takeaway service will also continue to be open.Yes, gyms and indoor sports facilities including swimming pools and leisure centres will be open for inidual exercise.Group activity will be permitted for under s.No, contacts sports are not permitted until Level .No, cinemas, theatres, concert halls, music venues, comedy clubs, amusement arcades, bingo halls and other entertainment centres cannot reopen until Level .Yes, groups of six people from up to twohouseholds may socialise indoors in a public place. This does not includein-house socialising.However, one substantial change is that, from April , a maximum of sixpeople from up to sixhouseholds can meet outdoors.It is worth noting that under s do not count towards restricted numbers or households outdoors.These will beclosedwith the exception of drive-in events.You should continue to active travelwhere possible and avoid car sharing with people outside of your extended household.Face coverings compulsory on public transport and, due to limited capacity,you are using public transport then plan ahead.Nurseries, childminders and regulated school-age childcare providers are open.Informal childcare such as family and friendsare permitted.Yes, but it will be subject to guidance.Yes, all visitors centres can reopen for business.You are encouraged to work from home where possible.Yes, but the recommended family support from at least onevisitor per patient.Yes, however, the recommended minimum of twovisits per week, one person at a time. It should be essential visits only at all times.Yes, but it willbeblended learning.Yes, and  people are allowed to attend the ceremony and thewedding reception.Alcohol is also permitted.A maximum of  people are allowed to attend a funeral service and alcohol is permitted.Yes, places of worship will be open.Yes, all public buildings are allowed toreopen on April .Yes, driving lessons will be restarted.Work, such as home decorating, repairs etc areallowed indoors.Yes, you are allowed to move home.

title: primark-glasgow-opening-times-revealed-lockdown-eases-monday
story: The bargain giant has revealed its new opening times as staff are restocking their shelves and getting set to welcome customers back for the first time this year.Although shoppers wont be treated to a-hour reopening seen last year, some stores are reopening their doors at am while others will operate for  hours.A Primark spokeswoman said: "We are really looking forward to welcoming our customers back to our stores in Scotland."We know our customers will love our amazing new Spring Summer ranges, including bright leisurewear in spring pastels, as well as some exciting new collaborations with Disney and Pineapple, which will all be in-store when we re-open."As always, safety remains our top priority and we will continue to have extensive safety measures in place to help ensure that our employees and customers cantoPrimarkwith confidence.Other reopening times can be checked HERE.

title: musselburgh-covid-testing-centre
story: Talks are under way between East Lothian Council and the Scottish Government over the recommissioningof Stoneyhill Community Centre in Musselburgh as a testing centre.A report which will go before elected members next week warns that testing will be a constant in peoplersquos lives in the future.And it reveals that the community centre, which was listed by the local authority in  as an asset transfer, is at the centre of current plans.The report says: ldquoTesting for Covid- is likely to become a permanent feature in our lives ndash though one whose form will continue to change and adapt as the pandemic does.ldquoWork is under way in collaboration with the Scottish Government to assess the viability of the former Stoneyhill Community Centre, Musselburgh, being recommissioned to form part of the asymptomatic community testing offer ndash and possibly the symptomatic testing offer.: Mobile testing in countyAdditional plans under discussion are the introduction of a lsquopop-uprsquo mobile testing unit which could be based in a refitted bus or van and sent to hotspots as required.Stoneyhill Community Centre is a Category-C listed building built just after the Second World War and described as aphilanthropic contribution to the community by Inveresk Paper Mills.It is one of only three sports buildings in Scotland listed as being built by a company for its workers.The building was taken over by the town council in  for a brief period, then adopted by Musselburgh Rugby Club.In , it was taken over by East Lothian Council after falling into disrepair but remained run by the club as a community resource centre.In , the council put it on a list of public buildings identied for community asset transfers, inviting local community groups to take it on.Now, councillors are being told it could be brought back into council use as a site for future Covid- testing.The report by council chief executive Monica Patterson outlines the potential use of the centre and asks members to note the ongoing work being carried out.

title: dunbear-sculpture-light-john-muirs-birthday
story: The naturalist and conservationist was born in the East Lothian town before moving with his family to America.There, he became a central figure in the formation of the US National Park system.Muir was born in  and died aged  on Christmas Eve , with the sculpture, between the A and Dunbarrsquos Asda store, lit up blue and white to mark his birthday.The sculpture was unveiled in November  and was named DunBear by Emily Hotchkiss, of Dunbar Grammar School.The work of art was created by renowned Scottish artist Andy Scott, who is also responsible for the Kelpies, near Falkirk.

title: lateral-flow-tests-scotland-book-free-home-covid-test
story: Nicola Sturgeon announcedthat Scotswill be able to order lateral flow tests for home delivery from Monday  April.The quick test packages are part of a universal testing initiative to be introduced across the country, following their introduction in England and for senior school pupils.Speaking at the Covid briefing, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon confirmed plans for Scots to haveaccess to the fastertests, which can give results within just  minutes.People can order test packages online for home delivery by following details on the Scottish Governmentrsquos website.Alternatively, the nose and throat swab tests can be collected from covid testing centres in the afternoons or early evening.You can order free packs of rapid lateral flow tests to be sent to your homeyou live in Scotland, are over  and:A rapid lateral flow testpack contains seventests.You can only order one pack per household each day.You can order a test here.If you have someone on the shielding list in your household or are planning to travel to a Scottish island, select yes when the site asksyou were asked to get tested by a local authority or by an NHS Public Health team.For those travelling to a Scottish island, they should also click Scotland under the where in the UK do you live question, eventhey live in England, Wales or Northern Ireland.Speaking at her dailybriefing, Ms Sturgeon said: "Two weeks ago I indicated that we would make lateral flow tests available to anyone in Scotland who wants one."I can confirm therefore that lateral flow testing will be available to anyone in Scotland from  April."You can order later flow test online for delivery to your home ndash and you can find information on how to do that on the Scottish Governmentrsquos website."Alternatively, you can collect the tests from Covid testing centres in the afternoon or early evening."I would encourage everyone to take advantage of this offer ndash but I want to highlight one issue in particular today where we are really encouraging people to make sure they use lateral flow testing as appropriate."Ifyou do not have coronavirus symptoms but live in a community that has been targeted for testing, you can access a test at a rapid test site.These are only available in some parts of Scotland.You can usually just turn up and do not need to book in advance ndash but you should check the arrangements at your local site first.You will be tested using a lateral flow devicewhich involves taking a swab or saliva sample.You should usually get your result within an hour.The First Minister also added that people visiting the islands should take two lateral flow tests before travelling.Nicola Sturgeon said: "We are keeping island communities at the same level as the rest of the country at the moment, so that we can allow travel between island communities and the rest of Scotland."But we know this does create a risk for our island communities."Many of them currently have very, very low rates of Covid."And they will be welcoming visitors from parts of Scotland which I know many of them are looking forward to where Covid will still be circulating at a higher level and more widely."So If you are planning to travel to an island we do encourage you to take two lateral flow tests before you depart."The second test should be on the day that you are planning to travel, and the first should be three days before you travel."That means thatyou test positive, you have a chance to take a PCR test - which is more sensitive - to confirm the result before making a
